I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Chongqing  Urban–Rural  Infrastructure 
Development Demonstration II Project.1 
 
2.  The  project  aims  to  attain  socially  inclusive  and  economically  balanced  growth  by 
integrating urban and rural development in Chongqing. The project will selectively enhance the 
development potential of medium-sized cities, small towns, and villages through (i) an inclusive 
urban water supply system, (ii) urban flood risk management for various-sized rivers, and  
(iii)  improved  urban–rural  road  connections.  Building  on  the  2010  project  experience,2 the 
project  will  demonstrate  new  approaches  for  integrated  urban–rural  development  including 
climate change adaptation, ecologically sound flood protection design, effective management of 
drinking water quality, and enhanced road safety in seven districts and counties in Chongqing.3 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Chongqing is one of four centrally administered municipalities in the PRC. It is a part of 
the less-developed western inland region targeted by the National Strategy for Development of 
the West, which has contributed significantly to accelerating Chongqing’s economic growth 
since  2001.  However,  the  economic  benefits  have  been  unevenly  distributed  due  to 
Chongqing’s  topographical  characteristics  of  vast  hinterlands,  and  predominantly  hilly  and 
mountainous terrain.4 In Chongqing, a few rapidly developing western central districts coexist 
with  high-poverty  peripheral  counties  in  the  northeast  and  southeast,  reflecting  wide 
development gaps.5 Imbalanced socioeconomic development is also evident within districts and 
counties with urban expansion into rural areas.6 In 2011, the ratio of per capita gross domestic 
product of the wealthiest district to the poorest county was 9:1; the ratio of the urban–rural 
average  income  of  Chongqing  was  3.3:1.  Two  million  rural  residents  still  lived  below  the 
designated poverty line of CNY2,300 per annum. 
 
4.  Chongqing is the first PRC provincial demonstration area to pilot urban–rural reforms. 
Since 2008 Chongqing has made continuous efforts to achieve more sustainable and socially 
inclusive development by reversing the trend of widening urban–rural development disparity. 
During 2008–2011, Chongqing invested CNY48.1 billion in public infrastructure and services to

address inequalities. The 2010 project is further strengthening basic infrastructure of small 
townships and villages in poor northeastern and southeastern regions.7 However, the progress 
of  closing  urban–rural  development  gaps  has  been  very  slow.  Chongqing  still  follows  a 
traditional centralized urban development pattern with the western central region producing 78% 
of its total gross domestic product and continuing as a major destination for rural migrant 
workers.8 In Chongqing, no other regional urban center exists along the Yangtze river economic 
corridor to rebalance its development. Many second- and third-tier cities remain less attractive 
for investment to support economic activities due to risks of frequent floods and lack of basic 
urban infrastructure. Many of the Chongqing’s remote rural towns and villages are left behind 
from its overall development because of the insufficient transport network and access roads. To 
rebalance development, Chongqing must support different levels of cities, towns, and villages to 
enhance its physical connectivity and economic competitiveness. The project will (i) strengthen 
the  development  potential  of Wanzhou to  become Chongqing’s second  regional center  by 
improving water supply service and drinking water quality; (ii) enhance flood resilience of county 
capitals and cities to meet their need to become local economic centers in Rongchang, Wulong, 
and Youyang counties; and (iii) provide better social and economic development opportunities 
by connecting isolated townships and poor villages in Chengkou and Shizhu counties, and 
Fuling district.  
 
5.  Demonstration  features.  The  project  incorporates  lessons  from  the  ongoing  2010 
project. The initial selection criteria for project components strongly emphasized supporting key 
regional cities, towns, and  villages.  Accordingly,  to  foster  urban–rural  integration, selection 
criteria  under  the  current  project  include  (i)  strong  demonstration  impact,  (ii)  geographic 
balance, and (iii) local project management and financial capacity.  The project will demonstrate 
the following special features of inclusive and environment–friendly urban–rural development in 
Chongqing: (i) climate-proofing design based on a detailed climate change impact assessment 
(for the first time in an ADB project in the PRC); (ii) application of the water safety plan (WSP) 
developed  by  the World  Health  Organization  to  systematically  address  the  risk  of  unsafe 
drinking water; (iii) adoption of an ecologically sound flood protection design that minimizes soil 
excavation and retains natural river flows; and (iv) implementation of enhanced road safety and 
engineering designs based on the needs of local residents. The project will directly benefit 25 
townships and 173 villages, while indirectly benefiting all districts and counties in Chongqing by 
demonstrating effective financial support to balance urban–rural development. 
 
6.  Strategic fit and lessons. The project aligns with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 
2011–2015 for the PRC9 and ADB’s water and urban operational plans,10 which emphasize the 
value of ensuring inclusive growth, environmentally sustainable growth, flood mitigation, and 
inclusive  water  policy  reforms;  and  enhancing  cities’  competitiveness  through  urban 
development.  The  project  supports  the  PRC’s  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015,  which 
targets  rising  income  inequality,  livelihood  improvement,  and  regionally  balanced  and 
environmentally sustainable growth to attain the long-term goal of building a harmonious and 
moderately  prosperous  society.  It  contributes  to  the  PRC’s  achievement  of  Millennium 
Development Goal 7.11 The project design incorporates lessons from the 2010 project and

include (i) use of well-defined criteria for selecting investment components, (ii) enhancement of 
the financial management capacity of project districts and counties to ensure timely provision of 
counterpart  funds,  and  (iii)  rigorous  review  of  technical  designs  to  enable  optimal  size  of

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The impact will be improved living standards and quality of life through more balanced 
urban–rural development in project districts and counties. The outcome will be improved access 
to safe drinking water and all-weather roads, and resilience to flood risk in the project districts 
and counties. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
8.  The project will have flood management, water supply and road network improvement 
components comprised of the following outputs: 
 
(i)  Rongchang Rongfeng river enhancement and flood management: a 6.7-
kilometer (km) dike with a bridge, related sewage pipelines, landscaping, and 
rainfall and floodwater monitoring equipment. 
(ii)  Wulong  Wujiang  river  flood  management:  2.6-km  dikes  with  floodwater 
monitoring equipment.  
(iii)  Youyang  Longtan  river  flood  management:  9.7-km  dikes  with  pedestrian 
footbridges, landscaping, and rainfall and floodwater monitoring equipment.  
(iv)  Chengkou urban–rural road network improvement: upgraded 10.2-km roads 
and related infrastructure, including bridges, a tunnel, stormwater drainage ditch, 
and landscaping. 
(v)  Fuling urban–rural road network improvement: upgraded 16.2-km roads and 
related  infrastructure,  including  bridges,  stormwater  drainage  ditch,  and 
landscaping. 
(vi)  Shizhu urban–rural road network improvement: upgraded 25.3-km roads and 
related infrastructure with bridges, stormwater drainage ditch, and landscaping. 
(vii)  Wanzhou  Yangliu  water  supply:  a  new  water  treatment  plant  (WTP)  with 
200,000 cubic meters/day (m3/day) capacity, a sludge treatment facility, water-
quality monitoring equipment, and other plant ancillary equipment. 
(viii)  Capacity development and institutional strengthening: capacity building and 
institutional  strengthening  of  project  management  including  financial 
management;  and  technical  support  and  training  on  project  implementation, 
operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  project  facilities,  public  financial 
management, expert advisory support on water sector reorganization and water 
safety plan, and upgrading of the existing flood early-warning and evacuation 
system to be more climate-resilient.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
13.  The project technical designs are based on locally proven reliable designs, as well as  
relevant PRC engineering guidelines and local regulations. Technical feasibility was assessed 
to be adequate after detailed examination of the project’s compatibility with local conditions 
including projections of water demand, required level of flood discharge, and function of roads. 
Alternative technical options identified the best alignment of tunnels, roads, and dikes; WTP 
location;  water  treatment  systems;  and  sludge  management  in  terms  of  economic  and 
safeguard aspects. The project will provide training under its capacity development component 
to ensure sustainable O&M of project facilities. Learning from the 2010 project, the project 
management consulting service includes six specialists with total inputs of 122 person-months 
for rigorous review of technical designs. The demonstration features of the project engineering 
design include (i) climate-proofing through a combination of engineering and nonengineering 
measures in Youyang and Wulong counties; (ii) ecologically sound river enhancement design by 
retaining natural hydrological features and habitat diversity, minimizing water pollution, and 
improving public access in Rongchang county; (iii) enhanced monitoring capacity and laboratory 
facilities to ensure sustainable delivery of safe drinking water based on the WSP in Wanzhou 
district; (iv) enhanced road safety in Fuling district, and Shizhu and Chengkou counties; and  
(v) upgraded web-based project management and information system to enhance institutional 
coordination.16  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
14.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was estimated by comparing with- and 
without-project  scenarios.  The  analysis  evaluated  technical  options  and  confirmed  that  all 
subprojects are the least-cost options to support Chongqing’s long-term development plans and 
each district and county master plan. The EIRRs are 15.3% for the overall project, 19.6% for the 
flood management component, 12.3% for the road component, and 13.9% for the water supply 
component; all exceed the economic opportunity cost capital of 12%.17 Quantifiable economic 
benefits  to  be  generated  by  project  interventions  include  (i)  increased  land  value  and 
development potential by minimizing flood risks, (ii) savings of vehicle operating costs and time, 
(iii)  income  gained from  year-round  road  access,  and (iv)  improved  water supply services 
measured through willingness to pay. Economic costs include capital costs including physical 
contingencies, and O&M costs. Sensitivity analysis indicates that the overall project EIRR will 
drop to 13.3% if benefits are reduced by 10%. However, qualitative benefits of improved access 
to  social  services,  and  reduced  economic  activities  from  flood  damage  are  not  included, 
suggesting that the project’s economic benefits would be higher than the projections. 
 
15.  The financial viability analysis of the revenue-generating Wanzhou Yangliu water supply 
subproject indicates that the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) is 6.1%, which exceeds the 
weighted average cost of capital of 3.7%. Sensitivity analysis indicates that the project is most 
sensitive to decreases in revenue, but the FIRR remains higher than the weighted average cost 
of capital at 4.4%. Water tariffs are expected to increase by 10.0% every 5 years, which is 
considered conservative compared with historical tariff revisions in Wanzhou.18 The analysis 
concluded  that  low-income  urban  households  will  be  able  to  afford  the  projected  tariff

poor household’s monthly income. The FIRR drops to 3.1% in the combined cases of (i) a 
10.0% increase in capital costs, (ii) a 10.0% decrease in revenue, and (iii) a 10.0% increase in 
operating costs. The tariff will be closely monitored and policy dialogue will be conducted during 
project implementation to ensure the subproject’s financial sustainability. 
 
16.  Financial analysis of nonrevenue-generating flood management and road components 
was carried out to ensure fiscal sustainability during implementation and operation. The fiscal 
impact on the project district and county governments was assessed by comparing annual 
revenues from identified financing sources with annual counterpart funds required for (i) capital 
expenditures during project implementation, and (ii) recurrent costs for subproject O&M and 
debt  service  during  operation.  The  analysis  indicates  that  all  subprojects  have  sufficient 
counterpart funds during project implementation and funds for O&M and debt service during 
operation. Annual counterpart funds and interest during construction will range from 0.3% to 
2.0% of projected fiscal revenues during implementation. O&M and debt service will range from 
0.1% to 0.7% of projected revenues in 2019 when principal repayment of the ADB loan will start. 
This indicates acceptable fiscal risk for the governments for counterpart funds. Training will be 
conducted to strengthen their capacity for public financial management.19  
 
C.  Governance 
 
17.  CMG and its Project Management Office have successfully managed complex urban 
sector projects funded by ADB and the World Bank. All project districts and counties have 
experience with projects financed by international financial institutes. Procurement capacity and 
financial management assessments conclude that the project district and county governments 
and the project implementing units (PIUs) have adequate capacity for procurement and financial 
management  in  accordance  with  ADB  policies  and  procedures,  and  national  laws  and 
regulations.  The  project  district  and  county  governments  follow  the  domestic  procurement 
processes  of the  PRC Tendering  Law  and Chongqing Municipality  Tendering  Regulations. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date), and Accountability Mechanism Policy 
(2012) were explained to and discussed with CMG, the project district and county governments, 
and the PIUs. The project district and county governments and the PIUs are receiving practical 
knowledge support for procurement, financial management, and governance issues from the 
districts and counties participating in the 2010 project. Training will be provided to enhance PIU 
financial management and internal audit system. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
18.  An estimated 259,903 people will benefit directly from the project. Six of the seven 
project districts and counties are designated poverty counties with poverty incidence of 14%–
30%. The average rural poverty rate in villages in project areas is about 10%, with one reaching 
24% (Chengkou). The project’s improvement of resilience to flood events, urban–rural road 
networks,  and  access  to  safe  drinking  water  will  contribute  to  more  balanced  social  and 
economic development by (i) supporting development of key cities and towns in poor counties, 
and (ii) reducing constraints on socioeconomic development in more isolated, poor rural areas. 
The improved water supply services will provide better public health. The flood management 
component will reduce economic loss for poor urban families from crop damage and attract 
more investment in county urban centers. Road improvements will increase the incomes of poor 
rural farmers by (i) providing them with better options for marketing their goods, (ii) reducing 
                                                
19  Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
transport costs and travel time, and (iii) enabling them to grow cash crops. In addition, the 
project will have more indirect benefit to overall Chongqing by its demonstration impact and 
replication potential. A social action plan to ensure inclusive benefits will be monitored by a 
resettlement and social development specialist.20 
 
19.  Gender benefits. The project is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming. Results 
from the household survey and focus group discussions indicate that the primary responsibilities 
of  women  involve  all  housekeeping  activities,  care  of  family  members,  and  crop  farming. 
Women in isolated villages are particularly affected by poor mobility and lack of job opportunity. 
The project will significantly improve their mobility and access to social services, employment, 
and income opportunities. The project includes a gender action plan (GAP) to help ensure 
targets and activities such as (i) increased women’s participation in the project, including a 
target of at least 30% employment opportunities for women, the poor, and/or ethnic minorities 
during construction; (ii) women’s participation in gender-sensitive training on public road safety 
and water conservation programs; (iii) sex disaggregated baseline and survey data collection; 
and  (iv)  implementation  and  monitoring  of  the  GAP  indicators.  The  district  and  county 
governments with the assistance of the resettlement and social development specialist are 
responsible for GAP implementation, and reporting on project progress and achievements.21 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
20.  Environment. The project is classified category A for environment. The categorization 
was  mainly  triggered  by  (i)  earthwork  and  soil  erosion  related  to  road  construction  in 
mountainous terrain; (ii) potential impacts on physical cultural resources in Youyang and Shizhu 
counties, and municipal nature reserves in Fuling district and Shizhu county; (iii) the safety of 
the Yangliu WTP operations in Wanzhou district; and (iv) impacts of the river enhancement and 
flood management components in Rongchang, Wulong, and Youyang counties on river ecology 
and downstream areas. The subprojects’ scope, project sites, road alignments, and the design 
of flood control works were adjusted at the feasibility study stage to minimize land acquisition 
and earthwork, and avoid impacts on sensitive areas. An environmental impact assessment 
(EIA) was prepared and posted on the ADB website on 15 August 2012.22 The EIA complies 
with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  EIA  concludes  that  anticipated 
environmental impacts and risks can be mitigated through implementation of the environmental 
management  plan  (EMP),  which  defines  mitigation  measures,  monitoring  requirements, 
institutional responsibilities, and training and institutional strengthening plans to ensure proper 
environmental management throughout project construction and operation. The EMP includes 
specific safeguard plans addressing the major anticipated impacts, including (i) soil erosion 
protection plans for each subproject, (ii) a physical cultural resources risk management plan, 
and  (iii)  a  WSP  for  the  Wanzhou  Yangliu  water  supply  plant  subproject.  Environmental 
management  is  supported  by  loan  covenants  and  capacity  development  and  institutional 
strengthening activities under the project. The project district and county governments disclosed 
relevant environment information to potentially affected people, and the results and findings of 
the consultation process were used to modify project design and the EIA. Consultation and 
public  participation  will  continue  throughout  project  implementation  and  any  environmental 
complaints or disputes will be handled in accordance with the grievance redress mechanism 
defined for the project. 
                                                
20 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). The  
social action plan is included in the PAM. 
21 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
22 Environmental Impact Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
21.  Involuntary  resettlement.  The  project  is  classified  category  A  for  involuntary 
resettlement.23 Seven  resettlement  plans  prepared  in  line  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) were approved by ADB and the project district and county governments, 
disclosed to the affected persons, and uploaded to the ADB website by 10 April 2013. Overall, 
the project will affect 3,221 persons, of which 321 will be relocated. The project will permanently 
acquire 2,117 mu of collective and state-owned land, temporary acquire 370 mu of land, and 
demolish 14,520 square meters (m2) of residential and nonresidential buildings.24 The project 
district and county governments have stated that the funds for involuntary resettlement will be 
made available on time. Capacity development and institutional strengthening activities will 
support  implementation  of  the  resettlement  plans,  which  will  be  monitored  and  evaluated 
internally and externally. The project district and county governments, and PIUs, which have at 
least  two  full-time  staff  responsible  for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  will  report 
implementation progress regularly to CMG, which will summarize the progress in the quarterly 
progress report to ADB. The external monitor will review the progress and general welfare of 
affected persons to assess whether they have fully regained their standard of living. Monitoring 
and evaluation reports will be prepared semiannually during implementation and annually for 2 
years  after  resettlement  completion,  and submitted  and  published  on the  ADB  website.  A 
transparent grievance channel will provide a meaningful consultation mechanism, and trigger 
remedial action defined for the project. 
 
22.  Indigenous peoples. The project is classified category B for the indigenous peoples 
safeguard. Shizhu and Youyang counties are autonomous ethnic minority counties and are also 
designated poverty counties. Two ethnic minority development plans were prepared, approved 
by ADB and the project district and county governments, and disclosed to the affected persons 
by 9 April 2013 to facilitate their participation and inclusion in the project benefits. Both Tujia and 
Miao people in Chongqing are fully integrated, both socially and economically, with the Han 
population. Ethnic minority lands to be affected by the project have formal legal titles, and will 
receive  full  compensation.  The  poverty  and  social  assessment  survey  and  consultations 
concluded that all beneficiaries, including ethnic minorities, will equally benefit from the project. 
There will be no adverse impacts other than resettlement impacts on 1,001 ethnic minority 
persons and construction of their new houses. The overall project design includes prioritization 
of ethnic minorities for construction jobs and O&M activities and the use of the local language, 
where necessary, in communication and outreach for consultations.

IV.  ASSURANCES  
 
24.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the project 
administration manual and loan documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan and project agreements. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
25.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$150,000,000 to the People’s Republic of China for the Chongqing Urban–Rural Infrastructure 
Development Demonstration II Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to 
be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 6 years; and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project 
agreements presented to the Board.
